title: Method and System for Water Treatment for Increasing Hydrocarbon Recovery from HydrocarbonReservoirs
description: A first stream of an aqueous solution flows through an upstream desalination or nanofiltration system. A second stream of the aqueous solution is mixed with the diluate output from the upstream desalination system or with the diluate or concentrate output from the upstream nanofiltration system with a flow ratio of the second stream of the aqueous solution to the feed stream of < 0.47 or > 0.63. A liquid composition flows into the concentrate channels of an electrically driven separation apparatus, while the feed stream flows into at least the diluate channels at a ratio of 0.3 to 0.81 to the flow of the liquid composition. An applied voltage selectively draws monovalent ions from the feed stream in the diluate channels through the monovalent-selective ion exchange membranes into the concentrate channels to produce a treated diluate having a sodium chloride ratio (SCR) < 0.7.
Description: A first stream of an aqueous solution flows through an upstream desalination or nanofiltration system. A second stream of the aqueous solution is mixed with the diluate output from the upstream desalination system or with the diluate or concentrate output from the upstream nanofiltration system with a flow ratio of the second stream of the aqueous solution to the feed stream of < 0.47 or > 0.63. A liquid composition flows into the concentrate channels of an electrically driven separation apparatus, while the feed stream flows into at least the diluate channels at a ratio of 0.3 to 0.81 to the flow of the liquid composition. An applied voltage selectively draws monovalent ions from the feed stream in the diluate channels through the monovalent-selective ion exchange membranes into the concentrate channels to produce a treated diluate having a sodium chloride ratio (SCR) < 0.7.
LLM Summary: ### Summary:\\nThe described method and system utilize a two-stream process for water treatment aimed at enhancing hydrocarbon recovery from hydrocarbon reservoirs. The first stream of an aqueous solution is processed through a desalination or nanofiltration system. The second stream is mixed with the output from the first system, maintaining specific flow ratios. A liquid composition is then directed into an electrically driven separation apparatus, which employs monovalent-selective ion exchange membranes to extract unwanted ions, resulting in a treated diluate with a sodium chloride ratio of less than 0.7.\\n\\n### Applications:\\nThis technology can be applied in the oil and gas industry, particularly for enhancing hydrocarbon recovery from reservoirs by improving the quality of water used in extraction processes. It may also be beneficial in other sectors requiring the treatment of aqueous solutions for the removal of monovalent ions.\\n\\n### Problem Solved:\\nThe technology addresses the issue of high sodium chloride concentration in the water used for hydrocarbon recovery, which can hinder extraction efficiency. By providing a method to reduce the sodium chloride ratio in treated effluent, it enhances the capability to recover hydrocarbons from reservoirs, thus improving overall operational effectiveness and potentially reducing costs associated with water quality management in hydrocarbon extraction.
LLM Teaser: A first stream of an aqueous solution is processed through an upstream desalination or nanofiltration system, while a second stream is mixed with the diluate output from the desalination or nanofiltration system at a specified flow ratio. The resulting liquid composition is then directed into the concentrate channels of an electrically driven separation apparatus.

title: Two Wave Coupling Using Phase ChirpedResonators
description: This invention is suited for applications in communications, radar, broadcasting and astronomy.\\n\\nTechnology: This invention is a frequency-chirped nano-antenna that provides efficient sub-wavelength vertical emission from a dielectric waveguide. This nano-antenna consists of a set of plasmonic dipoles (resonators) on the opposite side of a Si3N4 waveguide from a ground plane. The resulting structure, which is less than half a wavelength long, emits a broadband beam that can be coupled into an optical fiber. Because this coupling structure is short, it is suitable for vertical coupling in Silicon On Insulator (SOI) based Optical Phased Arrays (OPAs).\\n\\nProblem Addressed: Conventional vertical couplers are designed to be large to maximize coupling efficiency. This size limits the coupler bandwidth and usefulness for other application, such as Optical Phased Arrays (OPAs). Therefore, there is a need for compact couplers that have high coupling efficiency.\\n\\nAdvantages: Better coupling efficiency than traditional vertical couplers. Reduced element size

LLM Summary: **Summary:**  \\nThe technology titled 'Two Wave Coupling Using Phase Chirped Resonators' involves a frequency-chirped nano-antenna designed to achieve efficient sub-wavelength vertical emission from a dielectric waveguide. It comprises a set of plasmonic dipoles (resonators) positioned opposite a Si3N4 waveguide to a ground plane. The structure is smaller than half a wavelength, enabling it to emit a broadband beam that can be effectively coupled into optical fibers. This compact arrangement is particularly advantageous for vertical coupling in Silicon On Insulator (SOI) based Optical Phased Arrays (OPAs).\\n\\n**Applications:**  \\nThis invention is applicable in various fields including communications, radar, broadcasting, and astronomy.\\n\\n**Problem Solved:**  \\nThe technology addresses the limitations of conventional vertical couplers, which are typically large to enhance coupling efficiency but consequently restrict bandwidth and applicability in other domains like Optical Phased Arrays (OPAs). The invention offers a solution with compact couplers that maintain high coupling efficiency, thus expanding their potential applications.
LLM Teaser: This invention features a frequency-chirped nano-antenna composed of plasmonic dipoles on one side of a Si3N4 waveguide, enabling efficient sub-wavelength vertical emission. It is designed for applications in communications, radar, broadcasting, and astronomy.

title: RNA Engineering for CRISPR Synthetic Circuits and EndogenousRegulation
description: Various aspects and embodiments of the present disclosure relate to methods and compositions that combine multiple mammalian RNA regulatory strategies, including RNA triple helix structures, introns, microRNAs, and ribozymes with Cas-based CRISPR transcription factors and ribonuclease-based RNA processing in human cells. The methods and compositions of the present disclosure, in some embodiments, enable multiplexed production of proteins and multiple guide RNAs from a single compact RNA-polymerase-II expressed transcript for efficient modulation of synthetic constructs and endogenous human promoters.\\nThe generation of robust, scalable gene networks that interfere minimally with endogenous cellular processes is fundamental to synthetic biology. The use of RNA regulatory strategies in combination with CRISPR/Cas transcription factors (CRISPR-TFs) allows for the conditional regulation of large-scale synthetic and endogenous gene networks in eukaryotic cells. The system is uniquely suited to build sophisticated circuits and transcriptional cascades that could be linked to specific events (e.g., cell cycle) or environments (e.g., chemical gradients).\\n\\nTechnology: Here we describe a genome editing toolkit for the generation of robust, scalable synthetic gene networks and native gene modulation in eukaryotic cells. Existing CRISPR/Cas methodology cannot be used for conditional gene regulation, as the guide RNAs (gRNAs) used to target DNA sites can only be expressed from RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) promoters, most of which are constitutively active. This technology produces gRNAs from RNA polymerase II (RNAP II) promoters, allowing for conditional gene expression and tunable responses to external inputs. The system integrates CRISPR-TFs with RNA regulatory machinery (e.g., Csy4 endonuclease, RNA triple helix) to produce functional gRNAs from RNAP II promoters while preserving downstream translation and expression of the harboring gene. The system is capable of multiplexed gRNA expression from one individual transcript, thus modulating multiple nodes from a single one and enabling sophisticated regulatory circuits with a large number of interconnections.\\n\\nProblem Addressed: Current methods for genome editing (e.g., CRISPR/Cas) have the potential to modulate gene expression in a tunable manner but are often limited by a combination of scalability, lack of conditional regulation, and inefficient regulation of endogenous promoters. This genome engineering toolkit provides the means to regulate and synchronize multiplexed, large-scale synthetic gene networks in addition to modulating endogenous gene expression.\\n\\nAdvantages: Multiplexed, large-scale genome engineering. Synthesize multi-stage transcriptional cascades. Regulate synthetic and endogenous networks

The system is capable of multiplexed gRNA expression from one individual transcript, thus modulating multiple nodes from a single one and enabling sophisticated regulatory circuits with a large number of interconnections.\\n\\nProblem Addressed: Current methods for genome editing (e.g., CRISPR/Cas) have the potential to modulate gene expression in a tunable manner but are often limited by a combination of scalability, lack of conditional regulation, and inefficient regulation of endogenous promoters. Synthesize multi-stage transcriptional cascades. Regulate synthetic and endogenous networks
LLM Summary: **Summary:**\\n\\nThis technology focuses on RNA engineering methods that integrate various mammalian RNA regulatory strategies—including RNA triple helix structures, introns, microRNAs, and ribozymes—with CRISPR-based transcription factors and ribonuclease processes. It aims to enhance the efficiency of producing proteins and guide RNAs from single RNA-polymerase-II expressed transcripts in human cells. The integration of these techniques enables the development of scalable gene networks with minimal disruption to natural cellular functions, facilitating conditional regulation of synthetic and endogenous gene networks in a eukaryotic context.\\n\\n**Applications:**\\n\\nThe technology can be used in synthetic biology to create advanced gene networks that allow for conditional regulation based on specific biological events, such as the cell cycle, or environmental conditions, like varying chemical gradients. It also holds potential applications in tissue engineering, gene therapy, and the development of synthetic circuits for research and therapeutic purposes.\\n\\n**Problem Solved:**\\n\\nThis technology addresses the limitations of existing CRISPR/Cas approaches that do not permit conditional gene regulation, resolving the challenges of achieving precise control over gene expression in eukaryotic cells. By providing a toolkit that combines multiple RNA regulatory mechanisms with CRISPR capabilities, it facilitates the creation of complex and efficient gene networks while minimizing interference with endogenous biological processes.
LLM Teaser: The disclosed methods and compositions integrate various mammalian RNA regulatory strategies, such as RNA triple helix structures, introns, microRNAs, and ribozymes, with Cas-based CRISPR transcription factors and ribonuclease-based RNA processing in human cells. These approaches facilitate the multiplexed production of proteins and multiple guide RNAs from a single compact RNA polymerase.
